moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Bxc6: The exchange variation of the common Roy Lopez. White eliminates the many defender of e5 creating a very real weakness on e5. On the flip side white gives up the prized LSB.
moves.4... dxc6 5. Nc3 Bg4: black tries to defend the e-pawn by pinning the knight, but gives up valuable king side space.
moves.6. h3 Bh5:
!? better is 
Alternative variation: 6... Bxf3 7. Qxf3 Ne7 [with approximate equality]
moves.8... Qe7:
!?
Alternative variation: 8... Nf6 9. d3 Nd7 10. Nxd7 Qxd7
Alternative variation: 8... Bb4 9. d3 Qe7 10. Nxg6 hxg6 11. Bd2
moves.9... O-O-O 10. Be3: defending d4, developing a piece and anticipating ..c5 maybe.
moves.10... c5 11. Nxg6: a good move that forces black to play defence and allows white time to play d4-d5 with a positionally won game.
moves.11... hxg6 12. d5: It is now white's game to win but can he find the right plan?
moves.12... f5 13. exf5:
?!
No he can not! This is not as good because it weakens white's central dominance and secondly it allows black to untangle his bad queen side pawns.  The end result is that white has no chance of moving the d-pawn forward. Instead it becomes the victim of attack. 
Alternative variation: [ better is ] 13. Qf3 fxe4 14. Nxe4 Re8 15. Nc3 Qf6 16. Qg2
moves.13... gxf5 14. Qf3 fxg4 15. Qxg4+:
?!
Alternative variation: [better is ] 15. hxg4 Rxh1+ 16. Qxh1 Qd7 17. g5
moves.15... Kb8 16. O-O-O Nf6: White's advantage has been neutralized and black is now back in the game.
moves.17. Qc4: A good move that adds support to d5 and prepares for a4-a5.
moves.17... Rh5 18. h4 Re5 19. Bg5: Alternative variation: [better is ] 19. Bf4 Rf5 20. a4 Qe8 21. a5 Bd6 22. Be3
moves.19... Qf7 20. f4 Re3 21. f5 Rf3 22. Rhf1: Alternative variation: 26. Re6 [slightly better maybe is ] 26... Ne5 27. Qf1 Qxf5 28. Re8+ Ka7 29. Rxf8 Qxf8 30. Qxf8 Bxf8 31. Ne4
moves.26... Nf6 27. Kb1 Be5 28. Na4: Alternative variation: [positionally better is ] 28. Ne4 Qxd5 29. Bxf6 Bxf6 30. Nxf6 Qxf3 31. Rxf3 Rxf6 32.Kc1
moves.28... Bd6: Black is hold for the draw here despite white being up a pawn.
moves.29. c4:
!?
Alternative variation: [white can improve his pieces with ] 29. Be3 b6 30. Nc3 Nh5 31. Ne2
moves.32. Nc3 Qd7 33. Ne4: white should have done this four moves ago. Now it carries very little sting.
moves.33... Re8 34. Nxc5 Bxc5 35. Rxf5: white has a slightly more active position but the presence of a weak back rank guarantees the draw for black.
moves.35... Re1+ 36. Bc1 Qe7 37. Kc2 Rh1 38. B:
?
Alternative variation: [almost necessary was ] 38. Bd2 Rxh4 39. Bc3 g5 40. Re5 [=]
moves.38... Qe1: Alternative variation: 38... Rh2+ 39. Kd1 Qe8 40. Bf4 Rh1+ 41. Kc2 Qa4+ 42. Qb3 Qd7 43. Qd3 Rxh4 [[%t Long] ⩱]
A fine result, but maybe white could have had more but we will never know.
